content: I started watching Generation Kill today. Is that really what some of the Marines and Soldiers are like? Do they bash on the kids and adults that send them letters and care packages? And do they always talk like that? For example, when the guy from Rolling Stones came. Please don't get me wrong, I have all the respect and appreciation for our military. I'm even thinking of enlisting myself, but when I see those things it just makes me think twice. Is that what it will be like?

title: Generation Kill-Is it accurate?

content: Keep in mind it's a mini-series made by "Hollywood" for HBO! If it was a documentary airing on the military channel it would be more true to fact. Hit the "Find" button at the top, above your post and do a search for "Generation Kill".... There have been many threads about it. Some discussions by those who have actually been there. GOD BLESS AMERICA! GOD BLESS OUR MILITARY!

content: quote: Originally posted by 20594712: And do they always talk like that? For example, when the guy from Rolling Stones came. I watched that series about a month ago. Like "Band of Brothers", I thought it was an outstanding show. My son has been a Marine for three years now. When he is home on leave he dropped the F-bomb way too often. I understand though and just ask him to lighten up with it when he is around his younger brother. I remember coming home after my first 2 month patrol on a Coast Guard cutter. I was 19 and sitting at the table for dinner with my parents and brothers. "Pass the F-ing potatoes, please." My parents just looked at me and didn't say a word. I apologized. It was just the way most people talked, not saying it was right. When people are around traumatic events, they deal with it in their own way. I remember being at a friend's BBQ, we were all cops of some kind. We'd get talking about a boating fatality like most people talk about sports. We looked back and the wives and girlfriends were horrified at how causual we were in talking about someone dying. If you do go into the service, just be yourself. If you can fight off turning out that way then great for you. No one has to be that way and I doubt anyone wants to. Like I said, often times it's just the way people deal with death. Good luck to you, Don Proud father of a US Marine, Cpl, AAV's
quote: Originally posted by 20594712: And do they always talk like that? For example, when the guy from Rolling Stones came.
reply: I watched that series about a month ago. Like "Band of Brothers", I thought it was an outstanding show. My son has been a Marine for three years now. When he is home on leave he dropped the F-bomb way too often. I understand though and just ask him to lighten up with it when he is around his younger brother. I remember coming home after my first 2 month patrol on a Coast Guard cutter. I was 19 and sitting at the table for dinner with my parents and brothers. "Pass the F-ing potatoes, please." My parents just looked at me and didn't say a word. I apologized. It was just the way most people talked, not saying it was right. When people are around traumatic events, they deal with it in their own way. I remember being at a friend's BBQ, we were all cops of some kind. We'd get talking about a boating fatality like most people talk about sports. We looked back and the wives and girlfriends were horrified at how causual we were in talking about someone dying. If you do go into the service, just be yourself. If you can fight off turning out that way then great for you. No one has to be that way and I doubt anyone wants to. Like I said, often times it's just the way people deal with death. Good luck to you, Don Proud father of a US Marine, Cpl, AAV's
title: Generation Kill-Is it accurate?

content: Gotta agree with ya Don. When I was one of the first E.M.T.'s in N.H. in 73 after a few years we built up quite a reserve of "black humor" that shocked silly those who heard some of it unprepared! It's a defense mechanism, plain and simple. The need to laugh, or collapse into insane weeping at some of what we saw. The mutilation of kids on vacation in all kinds of grisly accidents. Whole families wiped out in car wrecks, you name it, we had to deal with it, as you well know your self. Am I proud of some of what we said?? Of course not!! Am I proud of what we DID?? You bet your sweet azz I am!!! There are still people walkin' around today who would be dead if we hadn't done as we did!! As a cop, then a fire fighter, then E.M.T. Then forming up a mountain rescue unit that still is operational, and Deputy Director of Civil Defense, I am proud indeed of all of us then!! T Of course now I'm just an old wreck but what the hey, there WAS a day!!

content: Finally saw Generation Kill myself recently. I wasn't a Marine or in Iraq, yet I was Army and in Desert Storm. But the Infantry is the Infantry, regardless of branch or war, and personally I found GK's depiction of Infantrymen to be pretty much spot on. The black humor, the raunchy jokes, how Grunts make the most of the worst living conditions - watching it I almost felt like I knew those guys.
reply: Finally saw Generation Kill myself recently. I wasn't a Marine or in Iraq, yet I was Army and in Desert Storm. But the Infantry is the Infantry, regardless of branch or war, and personally I found GK's depiction of Infantrymen to be pretty much spot on. The black humor, the raunchy jokes, how Grunts make the most of the worst living conditions - watching it I almost felt like I knew those guys.
title: Generation Kill-Is it accurate?

content: What people often fail to understand is that the humor, the language and the jokes are a defense mechanism. A means of getting through the day and the experiences you encounter. It doesn't mean the people are ignorant, stupid or rude. It just means they are dealing with things and processing a stressful situation the best way they can.
reply: What people often fail to understand is that the humor, the language and the jokes are a defense mechanism. A means of getting through the day and the experiences you encounter. It doesn't mean the people are ignorant, stupid or rude. It just means they are dealing with things and processing a stressful situation the best way they can.

content: quote: Originally posted by tawodi: Gotta agree with ya Don. When I was one of the first E.M.T.'s in N.H. in 73 after a few years we built up quite a reserve of "black humor" that shocked silly those who heard some of it unprepared! It's a defense mechanism, plain and simple. The need to laugh, or collapse into insane weeping at some of what we saw. The mutilation of kids on vacation in all kinds of grisly accidents. Whole families wiped out in car wrecks, you name it, we had to deal with it, as you well know your self. Am I proud of some of what we said?? Of course not!! Am I proud of what we DID?? You bet your sweet azz I am!!! There are still people walkin' around today who would be dead if we hadn't done as we did!! As a cop, then a fire fighter, then E.M.T. Then forming up a mountain rescue unit that still is operational, and Deputy Director of Civil Defense, I am proud indeed of all of us then!! T Of course now I'm just an old wreck but what the hey, there WAS a day!! Boy, howdy on the "Black Humor!" As a Marine, Firefighter, EMT, S&R, and even Animal Control, each has it's own flavor of black humor and most of it "amusing" only within it's own community for those with similar experiences. To those outside of such communities, we seemed very cold, callous, and unfeeling, but they didn't have the BTDT shirts, and could never easily understand. It is not our belief or disbelief that can make or unmake the fact. ~ Thomas Paine

content: Having been to Iraq twice, once during 2003, just as teh show shows, I found quite a bit very true. The language and off-color jokes, were abundant, if you don't laugh, you cry. I never knew anyone that didn't like the care packages. Oh someone might ***** a little and say, "not baby wipes again", but that was about the extent of it, and most people always wrote back if they were able. The thing I found the most true, was the silly, inane, uniform regs that command tried pushing, during a war. Blew my mind, totally , freaking stupid. I come in off a 14 hour mission, and some azzhat fobbit, is giving me grief, cuz my t-shirt isn't the right color.
